awd_titl_txt: Ecosystem Responses to Hurricanes Synthesis Workshop
awd_abstract_narration:
Three major hurricanes (Harvey, Irma, and Maria) made landfall in the United States during the fall of 2017. Catastrophic human, economic, and ecological effects occurred from the storm surge, saltwater intrusion, wind damage, and flooding. The number of storms, their intensity, the number that made landfall, and the catastrophic damage was remarkable. Global models predict hurricanes will increase and effected areas will change over the next century. Thus, synthesizing responses to severe tropical storm disturbances is needed to understand general patterns of impact and recovery. This award will provide workshop funds for researchers, experts, managers, and graduate students to develop a synthetic understanding of hurricane impacts on freshwater, estuarine, and terrestrial ecosystems. The proposed workshop will provide important opportunities for career advancement and training of underrepresented and early career scientists.

The unprecedented landfall of multiple major hurricanes in the United States presents a rare opportunity to document generalizable patterns in ecosystem response to extreme disturbance. The workshop will leverage the significant investment of the National Science Foundation in Hurricane Research following the devastating impacts of storms Harvey, Irma, and Maria in 2017 to generate a novel cross-system disturbance ecology synthesis. The synthesis will result from three major activities including: recruitment and workflow design, a three-day workshop, and post-workshop analysis and synthesis. The workshop will bring together research teams studying multiple ecosystem types (estuarine, freshwater, terrestrial) and ecosystem responses (physical, biogeochemical, organismal ? mobile vs sedentary, microbial, animal, and plant) to these hurricanes. The participants will merge diverse datasets into a common statistical framework and conduct synthetic analyses to identify shared and unique responses to different types of hurricane stressors. Both workshop and post workshop activities will yield an understanding of how ecosystems respond to severe disturbance and contribute a generalizable conceptual framework that is applicable across ecosystems and ecosystem components.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Tropical cyclones are one of the most powerful natural disturbances on planet earth but they are difficult to study.  While the seasonality of these storms is predictable, the exact location and intensity of individual storm events each year is unpredictable.  The unpredictable nature of these events makes it difficult to plan individual studies or research program’s around them.  Furthermore, each storm appears, at face value, to be unique, challenging our ability to make quantitative comparisons between events.  This has resulted in the peer reviewed literature describing how ecosystems respond to these perturbations being full of opportunistic case studies, instances where researchers were in the right place at the right time and were able to quantify storm impacts on the coastal ecosystem they study. 

While case studies are of tremendous value, the changing nature of tropical cyclones under climate change has created a serious need to advance the field toward a general understanding of what makes a storm more or less destructive and how we might manage coastal systems to enhance their resistance or resilience.  As our climate changes the frequency and intensity of tropical cyclones is increasing.  Furthermore, as waters warm, storms are occurring more frequently at higher latitudes, impacting coastal areas that historically did not often receive hurricane strikes.  These changes demand new approaches to studying tropical cyclone affects on coastal ecosystems.

To address this need we assembled participants from across the United States for a data synthesis and brain storming workshop held in Corpus Christi, TX in April of 2019.  We brought together 42 scientists from a variety of career stages, research backgrounds, and geographic regions, each bringing a unique perspective to the discussions.  Over three days we pooled our data, assembled conceptual models, built new collaborations, and sowed the seeds for new research directions.  We then continued this work through remote collaboration in the years that followed.   

The project was very successful, resulting in four peer reviewed publications, a publicly available dataset with details concerning thousands of ecosystem response time series, networking opportunities for early career scientists, and the launch of a Research Coordination Network to continue the work that began in 2019.  Our most fundamentally important advance from the work to date was the discovery that resistance and resilience to tropical cyclones appear to be diametrically opposed properties of coastal ecosystems and that strength on one axis typically indicates weakness on the other axis.  We observed this pattern repeated throughout our dataset and we believe this is the result of evolutionary selection tending to optimize populations of organisms for one strategy (e.g. resistance or resilience) over the other.  This is a major finding that is akin to other commonly recognized trade-offs such as r vs K selected species.  It is likely that the patterns we observed in coastal ecosystems will extend to other disturbance regimes as well, although more work is needed to test those ideas.

This finding also has important implications for coastal management given that resistance and resilience are often mentioned in the same sentence, with stated goals by management groups to enhance both.  Our work suggests that for a given habitat type (e.g. seagrass meadows, coastal marshes) or population you cannot have it both ways, managers will need to choose which property makes the most sense for a given coastal system and their stated goals.  However, at larger scales, managing a mosaic of resistance and resilience across the coastal land and sea-scape is an achievable goal to strive for.
